BIOS202
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of the thorax, building upon general principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and the first semester of year 2. The module prepares learners for future practical modules in both skill development and concept comprehension.

Module themes include the functional musculoskeletal anatomy of the chest wall, the anatomy and development of the heart, the structure of the lungs and more. Specialist subject knowledge is introduced through online resources which are investigated and discussed in interactive seminars. This knowledge is then applied in practical sessions which involve hands-on cadaveric experience, e.g., dissection. Led by expert tutors, learners collaborate as a team to investigate, and gain a deeper understanding of thoracic anatomy.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

● A detailed understanding of the gross and functional anatomy of the human thorax and its significance in various contexts.

● A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.

● An ability to collaborate and communicate confidently with peers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 2 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, learners conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of the thorax, exploring typical and atypical anatomy, microanatomy, thoracic imaging, clinical anatomy and the developmental basis of congenital defects. A typical week will see students' study from a variety of online material before gathering for an interactive, activity-based seminar. Following this, learning moves into the laboratory in HARC for a deeper, hands-on experience, as students, working in a team, will carefully undertake human dissection of the thoracic region. This cadaveric dissection and examination are supplemented with models and applied anatomy, such as medical imaging. Working collaboratively, learners begin to develop the skills required to be proficient in human dissection in preparation for the more advanced modules in year 3.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module introduces learners to the anatomy of the thorax. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills.

Learning activities, e.g., lectures and practical sessions, are centred on a series of themes. These are explored in order, as would be encountered during a systematic process of dissection. Themes include:

● The anatomy of the chest wall
● The anatomy of the superior mediastinum
● The anatomy of the heart and pericardium
● The anatomy of the lungs and pleura
● The anatomy of the inferior mediastinum

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

1. Online Preparatory Material: This is the form of online reading, videos and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming seminars and practicals.

2. Seminar: Interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts.

3. HARC Practical: Interactive exploration of key anatomical themes. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

4. Formative assessment: A quiz taken via the VLE – a form of assessment for learning to consolidate practical knowledge and prepare for the spotter assessment.

5. Independent learning: Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, preparation for lectures and practicals, revision study and work towards assessment.


A typical week for a student will see 1 to 1 and a half hours of online preparator material. A 1 hour seminar and 2 hours of practical dissection.

The nature and implementation of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research, which highlights how anatomical research informs examination and management of disease. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. The substance of learning anatomical resources reflects diversity of the wider population. Imagery and examples prioritise the inclusion of a diversity of body types, disabilities and skin tones incidentally, rather than as a specific focus. The communication assessment offers learners a choice of medium for their submission. This is a form of negotiated assessment which is inherently inclusive by offering learners the opportunity to remove potential barriers to achievement without having to request it as an adjustment.

Active learning: Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of structures encountered, and analyses of anatomical variations and pathologies requires problem-solving abilities. The act of contextualising this and applying to different states of anatomy further embeds this active element, i.e., comparing between different bodies in different states of dissection to appreciate what is removed and left behind. Interpretation of medical imaging adds another layer of active processing. Similarly, the poster assessment will necessitate a form of enquiry-based active learning for assessment. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts to peers as part of assessment is inherently active.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Spotters are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The poster assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge to near peers in a comprehensible and accessible manor. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Seminars are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a cadaveric dissection builds confidence in own skills. The communication assessment further embeds this by requiring dissemination of knowledge.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced, premium anatomy digital resources, e.g., Visible Body 3D models. These are used as part of independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. The VLE is used for formative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes, which simulate authentic cadaveric identification exercises. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of medical imaging applications, that learners explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology for communication.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy for this module incorporates the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The chosen assessments are highly authentic and will embed important graduate attributes.

Assessments include:

Anatomical Teaching Poster (40%). To be done individually and on an anatomical structure covered within the module so far. LOs 2-6 will be covered by this assessment. Posters are an authentic method of education as they are used extensively at scientific conferences and can be used in other fields such as public health. This poster task also fills the hallmarks of digital fluency and although not presented by the students, producing the poster will still give the students confidence in communicating their work.

Spotter Assessment (60%). This is a type of practical assessment commonly used in anatomy. Spotters are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Learner’s visit stations, at which they identify and explain anatomical features, as required. This may include a mix of prosected cadaveric specimens, models, medical imaging, etc. Questions will be layered to test increasing levels of complexity.

Reassessment will use a similar format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Describe relevant surface landmarks to guide the process of cadaveric examination of the thorax.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO2 Discuss the musculoskeletal components of the thorax in relation to their passive and dynamic functions.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO3 Explain the gross anatomy of major organs of the thorax and their neurovascular supply and lymph in relation to function.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO4 Examine the topographic, functional and developmental relationships between viscera of the thorax.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO5 Describe the significance of anatomical variation in the contexts of health and disease.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO6 Critically review the importance of anatomy in applications outside of a laboratory, including imaging studies and clinical examination.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Communicate scientific knowledge effectively and confidently to a specified audience using appropriate terminology.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 S2 Perform systematic examination of human cadaveric material in a safe and professional manner.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 S3 Show awareness of ethical and legal constraints of working with cadaveric material.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2

BIOS202
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of the thorax, building upon general principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and the first semester of year 2. The module prepares learners for future practical modules in both skill development and concept comprehension.

Module themes include the functional musculoskeletal anatomy of the chest wall, the anatomy and development of the heart, the structure of the lungs and more. Specialist subject knowledge is introduced through online resources which are investigated and discussed in interactive seminars. This knowledge is then applied in practical sessions which involve hands-on cadaveric experience, e.g., dissection. Led by expert tutors, learners collaborate as a team to investigate, and gain a deeper understanding of thoracic anatomy.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

● A detailed understanding of the gross and functional anatomy of the human thorax and its significance in various contexts.

● A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.

● An ability to collaborate and communicate confidently with peers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 2 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, learners conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of the thorax, exploring typical and atypical anatomy, microanatomy, thoracic imaging, clinical anatomy and the developmental basis of congenital defects. A typical week will see students' study from a variety of online material before gathering for an interactive, activity-based seminar. Following this, learning moves into the laboratory in HARC for a deeper, hands-on experience, as students, working in a team, will carefully undertake human dissection of the thoracic region. This cadaveric dissection and examination are supplemented with models and applied anatomy, such as medical imaging. Working collaboratively, learners begin to develop the skills required to be proficient in human dissection in preparation for the more advanced modules in year 3.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module introduces learners to the anatomy of the thorax. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills.

Learning activities, e.g., lectures and practical sessions, are centred on a series of themes. These are explored in order, as would be encountered during a systematic process of dissection. Themes include:

● The anatomy of the chest wall
● The anatomy of the superior mediastinum
● The anatomy of the heart and pericardium
● The anatomy of the lungs and pleura
● The anatomy of the inferior mediastinum

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

1. Online Preparatory Material: This is the form of online reading, videos and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming seminars and practicals.

2. Seminar: Interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts.

3. HARC Practical: Interactive exploration of key anatomical themes. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

4. Formative assessment: A quiz taken via the VLE – a form of assessment for learning to consolidate practical knowledge and prepare for the spotter assessment.

5. Independent learning: Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, preparation for lectures and practicals, revision study and work towards assessment.


A typical week for a student will see 1 to 1 and a half hours of online preparator material. A 1 hour seminar and 2 hours of practical dissection.

The nature and implementation of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research, which highlights how anatomical research informs examination and management of disease. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. The substance of learning anatomical resources reflects diversity of the wider population. Imagery and examples prioritise the inclusion of a diversity of body types, disabilities and skin tones incidentally, rather than as a specific focus. The communication assessment offers learners a choice of medium for their submission. This is a form of negotiated assessment which is inherently inclusive by offering learners the opportunity to remove potential barriers to achievement without having to request it as an adjustment.

Active learning: Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of structures encountered, and analyses of anatomical variations and pathologies requires problem-solving abilities. The act of contextualising this and applying to different states of anatomy further embeds this active element, i.e., comparing between different bodies in different states of dissection to appreciate what is removed and left behind. Interpretation of medical imaging adds another layer of active processing. Similarly, the poster assessment will necessitate a form of enquiry-based active learning for assessment. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts to peers as part of assessment is inherently active.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Spotters are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The poster assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge to near peers in a comprehensible and accessible manor. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Seminars are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a cadaveric dissection builds confidence in own skills. The communication assessment further embeds this by requiring dissemination of knowledge.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced, premium anatomy digital resources, e.g., Visible Body 3D models. These are used as part of independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. The VLE is used for formative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes, which simulate authentic cadaveric identification exercises. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of medical imaging applications, that learners explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology for communication.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy for this module incorporates the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The chosen assessments are highly authentic and will embed important graduate attributes.

Assessments include:

Anatomical Teaching Poster (40%). To be done individually and on an anatomical structure covered within the module so far. LOs 2-6 will be covered by this assessment. Posters are an authentic method of education as they are used extensively at scientific conferences and can be used in other fields such as public health. This poster task also fills the hallmarks of digital fluency and although not presented by the students, producing the poster will still give the students confidence in communicating their work.

Spotter Assessment (60%). This is a type of practical assessment commonly used in anatomy. Spotters are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Learner’s visit stations, at which they identify and explain anatomical features, as required. This may include a mix of prosected cadaveric specimens, models, medical imaging, etc. Questions will be layered to test increasing levels of complexity.

Reassessment will use a similar format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 2 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, learners conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of the thorax, exploring typical and atypical anatomy, microanatomy, thoracic imaging, clinical anatomy and the developmental basis of congenital defects. A typical week will see students' study from a variety of online material before gathering for an interactive, activity-based seminar. Following this, learning moves into the laboratory in HARC for a deeper, hands-on experience, as students, working in a team, will carefully undertake human dissection of the thoracic region. This cadaveric dissection and examination are supplemented with models and applied anatomy, such as medical imaging. Working collaboratively, learners begin to develop the skills required to be proficient in human dissection in preparation for the more advanced modules in year 3.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module introduces learners to the anatomy of the thorax. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills.

Learning activities, e.g., lectures and practical sessions, are centred on a series of themes. These are explored in order, as would be encountered during a systematic process of dissection. Themes include:

● The anatomy of the chest wall
● The anatomy of the superior mediastinum
● The anatomy of the heart and pericardium
● The anatomy of the lungs and pleura
● The anatomy of the inferior mediastinum

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

1. Online Preparatory Material: This is the form of online reading, videos and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming seminars and practicals.

2. Seminar: Interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts.

3. HARC Practical: Interactive exploration of key anatomical themes. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

4. Formative assessment: A quiz taken via the VLE – a form of assessment for learning to consolidate practical knowledge and prepare for the spotter assessment.

5. Independent learning: Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, preparation for lectures and practicals, revision study and work towards assessment.


A typical week for a student will see 1 to 1 and a half hours of online preparator material. A 1 hour seminar and 2 hours of practical dissection.

The nature and implementation of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research, which highlights how anatomical research informs examination and management of disease. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. The substance of learning anatomical resources reflects diversity of the wider population. Imagery and examples prioritise the inclusion of a diversity of body types, disabilities and skin tones incidentally, rather than as a specific focus. The communication assessment offers learners a choice of medium for their submission. This is a form of negotiated assessment which is inherently inclusive by offering learners the opportunity to remove potential barriers to achievement without having to request it as an adjustment.

Active learning: Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of structures encountered, and analyses of anatomical variations and pathologies requires problem-solving abilities. The act of contextualising this and applying to different states of anatomy further embeds this active element, i.e., comparing between different bodies in different states of dissection to appreciate what is removed and left behind. Interpretation of medical imaging adds another layer of active processing. Similarly, the poster assessment will necessitate a form of enquiry-based active learning for assessment. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts to peers as part of assessment is inherently active.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Spotters are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The poster assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge to near peers in a comprehensible and accessible manor. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Seminars are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a cadaveric dissection builds confidence in own skills. The communication assessment further embeds this by requiring dissemination of knowledge.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced, premium anatomy digital resources, e.g., Visible Body 3D models. These are used as part of independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. The VLE is used for formative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes, which simulate authentic cadaveric identification exercises. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of medical imaging applications, that learners explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology for communication.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy for this module incorporates the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The chosen assessments are highly authentic and will embed important graduate attributes.

Assessments include:

Anatomical Teaching Poster (40%). To be done individually and on an anatomical structure covered within the module so far. LOs 2-6 will be covered by this assessment. Posters are an authentic method of education as they are used extensively at scientific conferences and can be used in other fields such as public health. This poster task also fills the hallmarks of digital fluency and although not presented by the students, producing the poster will still give the students confidence in communicating their work.

Spotter Assessment (60%). This is a type of practical assessment commonly used in anatomy. Spotters are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Learner’s visit stations, at which they identify and explain anatomical features, as required. This may include a mix of prosected cadaveric specimens, models, medical imaging, etc. Questions will be layered to test increasing levels of complexity.

Reassessment will use a similar format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of the thorax, building upon general principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and the first semester of year 2. The module prepares learners for future practical modules in both skill development and concept comprehension.

Module themes include the functional musculoskeletal anatomy of the chest wall, the anatomy and development of the heart, the structure of the lungs and more. Specialist subject knowledge is introduced through online resources which are investigated and discussed in interactive seminars. This knowledge is then applied in practical sessions which involve hands-on cadaveric experience, e.g., dissection. Led by expert tutors, learners collaborate as a team to investigate, and gain a deeper understanding of thoracic anatomy.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

● A detailed understanding of the gross and functional anatomy of the human thorax and its significance in various contexts.

● A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.

● An ability to collaborate and communicate confidently with peers.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module is part of a series of practical anatomical modules for students on the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology, through which they explore the anatomy of different body regions. This module provides an advanced exploration of the anatomy of the thorax, building upon general principles and concepts attained in Years 1 and the first semester of year 2. The module prepares learners for future practical modules in both skill development and concept comprehension.

Module themes include the functional musculoskeletal anatomy of the chest wall, the anatomy and development of the heart, the structure of the lungs and more. Specialist subject knowledge is introduced through online resources which are investigated and discussed in interactive seminars. This knowledge is then applied in practical sessions which involve hands-on cadaveric experience, e.g., dissection. Led by expert tutors, learners collaborate as a team to investigate, and gain a deeper understanding of thoracic anatomy.

Attainment is assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessment.
Educational Aims
This module aims to develop in learners:

● A detailed understanding of the gross and functional anatomy of the human thorax and its significance in various contexts.

● A professional set of practical anatomical skills acquired through systematic cadaveric examination and appraisal.

● An ability to collaborate and communicate confidently with peers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a core component in Year 2 of the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. It is a practical module which includes access to cadaveric dissection in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

Over the course of a full semester, learners conduct a thorough and systematic exploration of the gross and functional anatomy of the thorax, exploring typical and atypical anatomy, microanatomy, thoracic imaging, clinical anatomy and the developmental basis of congenital defects. A typical week will see students' study from a variety of online material before gathering for an interactive, activity-based seminar. Following this, learning moves into the laboratory in HARC for a deeper, hands-on experience, as students, working in a team, will carefully undertake human dissection of the thoracic region. This cadaveric dissection and examination are supplemented with models and applied anatomy, such as medical imaging. Working collaboratively, learners begin to develop the skills required to be proficient in human dissection in preparation for the more advanced modules in year 3.

Learners are assessed through a mixture of written and practical assessments.
Outline Syllabus
This module is part of a series of practical human anatomy modules in the BSc Anatomy and Human Biology. Learners on the programme explore cadaveric anatomy through a regional approach, with a coordinated programme-level strategy for knowledge scaffolding and skills development. This module introduces learners to the anatomy of the thorax. Through exploration of these new regions, learners acquire new knowledge and elevate their existing skills.

Learning activities, e.g., lectures and practical sessions, are centred on a series of themes. These are explored in order, as would be encountered during a systematic process of dissection. Themes include:

● The anatomy of the chest wall
● The anatomy of the superior mediastinum
● The anatomy of the heart and pericardium
● The anatomy of the lungs and pleura
● The anatomy of the inferior mediastinum

Additionally, learners can engage with these themes and explore related topics independently through the VLE, digital anatomical models, reading lists and library resources.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

1. Online Preparatory Material: This is the form of online reading, videos and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming seminars and practicals.

2. Seminar: Interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts.

3. HARC Practical: Interactive exploration of key anatomical themes. Includes individual cadaveric examination and dissection. Takes place in the Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC).

4. Formative assessment: A quiz taken via the VLE – a form of assessment for learning to consolidate practical knowledge and prepare for the spotter assessment.

5. Independent learning: Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, preparation for lectures and practicals, revision study and work towards assessment.


A typical week for a student will see 1 to 1 and a half hours of online preparator material. A 1 hour seminar and 2 hours of practical dissection.

The nature and implementation of these methods is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research, which highlights how anatomical research informs examination and management of disease. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. The substance of learning anatomical resources reflects diversity of the wider population. Imagery and examples prioritise the inclusion of a diversity of body types, disabilities and skin tones incidentally, rather than as a specific focus. The communication assessment offers learners a choice of medium for their submission. This is a form of negotiated assessment which is inherently inclusive by offering learners the opportunity to remove potential barriers to achievement without having to request it as an adjustment.

Active learning: Cadaveric dissection is an extremely active process. It requires real-time synthesis and comprehension of the structures encountered to successfully progress. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of structures encountered, and analyses of anatomical variations and pathologies requires problem-solving abilities. The act of contextualising this and applying to different states of anatomy further embeds this active element, i.e., comparing between different bodies in different states of dissection to appreciate what is removed and left behind. Interpretation of medical imaging adds another layer of active processing. Similarly, the poster assessment will necessitate a form of enquiry-based active learning for assessment. Researching, summarising and communicating concepts to peers as part of assessment is inherently active.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Spotters are highly authentic in anatomy and offer a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge in different authentic contexts – cadaveric examination, problem-solving, imaging interpretation, etc. The poster assessment requires students to lead their own enquiry to select, appraise and concisely communicate specialist subject knowledge to near peers in a comprehensible and accessible manor. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Seminars are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a cadaveric dissection builds confidence in own skills. The communication assessment further embeds this by requiring dissemination of knowledge.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced, premium anatomy digital resources, e.g., Visible Body 3D models. These are used as part of independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. The VLE is used for formative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes, which simulate authentic cadaveric identification exercises. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of medical imaging applications, that learners explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology for communication.

Global citizenship: Anatomy is a globally connected professional community. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south. Learning and assessment activities are designed to promote teamwork, integrity and a broad cultural outlook. There is a strong ethical focus within the department which empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions.

Attendances will be recorded at scheduled teaching sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy for this module incorporates the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. The chosen assessments are highly authentic and will embed important graduate attributes.

Assessments include:

Anatomical Teaching Poster (40%). To be done individually and on an anatomical structure covered within the module so far. LOs 2-6 will be covered by this assessment. Posters are an authentic method of education as they are used extensively at scientific conferences and can be used in other fields such as public health. This poster task also fills the hallmarks of digital fluency and although not presented by the students, producing the poster will still give the students confidence in communicating their work.

Spotter Assessment (60%). This is a type of practical assessment commonly used in anatomy. Spotters are highly authentic and feature in medical Royal College entrance exams as a means of testing applied anatomical knowledge. Learner’s visit stations, at which they identify and explain anatomical features, as required. This may include a mix of prosected cadaveric specimens, models, medical imaging, etc. Questions will be layered to test increasing levels of complexity.

Reassessment will use a similar format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Health and Safety
Practical sessions take place in Human Anatomy Resource Centre (HARC), where all activity must comply with Human Tissue Authority (HTA) regulations. Learners must not be aged under 18.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Describe relevant surface landmarks to guide the process of cadaveric examination of the thorax.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO2 Discuss the musculoskeletal components of the thorax in relation to their passive and dynamic functions.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO3 Explain the gross anatomy of major organs of the thorax and their neurovascular supply and lymph in relation to function.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO4 Examine the topographic, functional and developmental relationships between viscera of the thorax.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO5 Describe the significance of anatomical variation in the contexts of health and disease.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 LO6 Critically review the importance of anatomy in applications outside of a laboratory, including imaging studies and clinical examination.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Communicate scientific knowledge effectively and confidently to a specified audience using appropriate terminology.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 S2 Perform systematic examination of human cadaveric material in a safe and professional manner.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
 S3 Show awareness of ethical and legal constraints of working with cadaveric material.
Liverpool campus · Semester 2
